All the files (Help System and content) are owned by user/group bin. When starting Eclipse using the start command.

After further investigation, we found that the eclipse directory is read-only on our server and there is a code in eclipse saying:

In LocationManager.computeDefaultConfigurationLocation()
// 1) We store the config state relative to the 'eclipse' directory if possible
// 2) If this directory is read-only 
//    we store the state in <user.home>/.eclipse/<application-id>_<version> where <user.home> 
//    is unique for each local user, and <application-id> is the one 
//    defined in .eclipseproduct marker file. If .eclipseproduct does not
//    exist, use "eclipse" as the application-id.

I think this design is really not good. Since on Linux/Unix platform, eclipse directory is read-only does not mean that the eclipse/configuration and eclipse/workspace directories are read-only.
